title: Will the U.S. Department of Justice approve AT&T's bid for Time Warner before 1 October 2017?
preds: Given the time and current status, and my objection to 0 and 100%

Usually, unless its a emergency, little of significance gets done in the Federal government on a Friday.  So I am going to assume this is NOT going to happen before weekend, and that means its going to finish as NO.
No, The Justice Department has not made trust busting a high priority this year.
Guess this isn't happening this week.

The Senate approved the appointment of Makan Delrahim to be the antitrust chief at the Justice Department by a vote of 73-31 late yesterday evening. http://www.foxbusiness.com/features/2017/09/27/senate-confirms-makan-delrahim-as-antitrust-chief-at-justice-department.html "The Justice Department's decision on whether to approve AT&T deal, and under what conditions, could be one of Mr. Delrahim's earliest and most consequential tasks. While Mr. Delrahim has been on the sidelines awaiting confirmation, the department has been deep into its investigation of the effects of the deal, which would combine a top wireless and cable provider with a major U.S. media and entertainment company.  "Mr. Delrahim, in answers to senators during the confirmation process, left himself room to maneuver. The AT&T deal is a vertical merger -- a transaction that combine firms at different parts of the supply chain -- and Mr. Delrahim noted that antitrust scholars generally believe vertical mergers raise less serious concerns than mergers that combine head-to-head competitors. But he also said there can be times when a vertical merger could have anticompetitive effects.  "Just because a transaction or particularly types of transactions have been approved in the past does not mean that they could not raise competitive concerns in the future," Mr. Delrahim wrote in response to questions from Sen. Al Franken (D., Minn.), who has voiced objections to the AT&T deal.  "Mr. Trump during the campaign said AT&T shouldn't be allowed to buy Time Warner, which owns CNN, because it would allow too much concentration of power in one company. Some Democrats have raised concerns that the merger could give AT&T the ability to impede the distribution of video content created by competitors, but they have likewise expressed concern that the president might attempt to use the government antitrust approval process as a way to exert leverage over CNN, a network Mr. Trump has criticized repeatedly for its coverage of him.  "When he appeared before the Senate Judiciary Committee in May, Mr. Delrahim pledged that his antitrust enforcement decisions would be free from political influence from the White House. 
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:   Given how important this decision is, and that it is somewhat controversial, I just don't think this merger is going to get the green light in the next 2 days.
We are very nearly out of time for this question.  But I cannot go to zero because there is ironically a somewhat higher probability in these very last days before the end of the month.
Passage of time and no word of anything.

The clock has almost run out, and there's still no formal appointment for the head of DoJ's Antitrust Division. Holding a 1% chance because this *could* happen at any time without a prior announcement.

http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/elizabeth-warren-lifts-hold-on-justice-department-antitrust-nominee/article/2635349 "Sen. Elizabeth Warren . . . has lifted her hold on President Trump's nominee to oversee the Justice Department's Antitrust Division, Makan Delrahim, meaning the Senate can vote to confirm Delrahim.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  It is the division of the DoJ that Delrahim will oversee that is reviewing this merger.  There would have to be an extraordinary alignment of the stars, I think, for his confirmation to go through (with another attempt to repeal Obamacare sucking up time and energy of the Senate) and him to review and sign off on the deal--all in under 8 days;  the confirmation vote is not on the Senate calendar yet, as far as I can tell.
Quick decission while North Korea is header no.1
There's only a week to go.
Money seems to be more influential now than in the past. Maybe we just know more. But favors or money will make this happen.
No final decision in the remaining 10 days for sure.
In such a short time there is little final outcome probable.
times running out, so much for a sure thing ;-)

Still on my countdown to zero with time running out. But ... I deeply sympathize with @Amazing-Criswell's ambivalence about the possibility of a last-minute decision here. It's not impossible by any means, which is why I'm not yet at 0 and probably never will be.
Following @Amazing-Criswell, but at a respectful distance.  Besides, I miss Gene Wilder.

Still radio silence from the DoJ, except for those rumors that they will approve by the end of this month.  Counting today, they have just eight days left to accomplish approval by the end of the month.  Still not seeing why they would approve without the new appointee in place.  But that assumption is definitely worthy of challenge, so I remain conflicted on this question.  What is tilting me to lower probability is that we are simply running out of time for this question, and there have been a series of unfulfilled predictions and leaks in the past.   But just watch the damn DoJ approve this on 9/29!  It is important to note that if one wants to get something done by a certain deadline, nothing spurs one to action like being on the verge of the very last day.   I am with Willie Wonka on this one:  https://youtu.be/Oci1CuCht7E
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
One of the highly controversial acquisitions in the US will not be completed while Trump's pick for DoJ's antitrust division is held back by the Senate since June.
rising slightly on some recent news re leaks from DOJ

"A green light from the government is expected this month, according to people close to the process who were not authorized to discuss it. The U.S. Department of Justice is in the final stages of its merger review, these people said." - http://www.latimes.com/business/hollywood/la-fi-ct-stankey-att-time-warner-culture-20170907-htmlstory.html "Last week, there was a DOJ leak saying the deal is on target to close later this month. This was the same kind of headline that came out in the summer. To be honest, we shrugged off the first report calling for a September closing as wishful thinking (our last merger update can be read here: AT&T And Time Warner: Latest Merger Update). The company itself continued to target the end of the year. But now we have the same leak again. This sure makes us think that there is something to it. At a Merrill media conference last week, the AT&T director who is currently in charge of integration planning and will be in charge of the legacy Time Warner business unit, John Stankey, was asked about the DOJ rumor. He maintained that the end of the year was the target, but he would be happy with an earlier closing. So he did not exactly endorse the rumor, but he certainly did not refute it. He explained that great strides were being made in the negotiations. "
https://seekingalpha.com/article/4106050-t-time-warner-coming-home-stretch "Trump said during his election campaign last year that he would block an AT&T takeover of Time Warner, but the antitrust source said Trump spoke too soon, as the AT&T bid poses fewer antitrust issues – it is a vertical integration and not a takeover of another wireless carrier like  AT&T’s failed bid to acquire Deutsche Telekom unit T-Mobile in 2011." ... "In an effort to win US regulatory approval, AT&T’s Stephenson has all but decided to divest Time Warner’s Cable News Network (CNN) to CBS Corporation. CBS, which lacks a 24-hour cable news channel but works closely with CNN through 60 Minutes, has been looking to acquire CNN for years." - http://www.atimes.com/att-ceo-stephenson-takes-alphabet-time-warner-bid/ So given its the DoJ who've been leaking that the merger will be approved by the end of the year, given that Stankey is ok with an earlier approval, and given that the rumour about CNN being sold out to CBS is true, then there's a reasonable chance that the merger will be approved by the end of this month. Might be just after the closing date though, which is an issue here.
CEO was recently quoted as saying "by the end of the year", rather than "by the end of the month".

Aside from the obvious "lobbyists in Washington" argument, decisions in this administration have been markedly right-leaning. From the FCC to the President's own deregulatory agenda, the pro-business bent of the Trump appointees is hard to dismiss.

From @Dsarin: "Donald Trump 'may block $85bn Time-Warner-AT&T merger unless 'CNN boss is ousted' 
http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world-0/us-politics/donald-trump-time-warner-atandt-merger-block-cnn-boss-jeff-zucker-ousted-a7829366.html" From @Anneinak: "http://www.knoxnews.com/story/opinion/columnists/mark-harmon/2017/08/30/hold-line-against-media-oligopolies/616407001/ "President Donald Trump derided the deal during the campaign, but his nominee for the antitrust division appears to have no problem with it. Twenty state attorneys general, however, have stepped into the void and have been deposing telecommunications company officials about anti-competitive implications. 
. . . 
"Since AT&T announced the Time Warner bid, AT&T has plunked down more than $8 million on lobbying, spread across 27 firms. 
. . . 
"Despite clear “red v. blue” political overtones, the real issue here is green, the color of money. Big-money players are buying oligopoly, economic concentration, and abuse of consumers and smaller competitors. 
~~~~~~~ 
COMMENT: Part of the question here is how fast can money talk? Will the talking be done by Oct 1st???"
Unlikely. President Trump has been accused of profiteering. His administration will likely prevent a merger until sometime next year.
(This forecast is the product of perverse incentives. A more responsible forecast would be 20%.)
Because America loves monopolies. And the burecrats love under the table bonuses they get for these type of mergers.
Not by the end of October but probably by the end of the year.
Continuing my countdown to 0. DoJ has a lot on its plate right now. Hard to see this happening with less than four weeks remaining in September.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
I bet Trump pressures on behalf of the merger
Doesn't look like it will happen before the deadline.

"advanced stage", but from other comments, this still seems like it might take this decision past the closing date.
http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/wall-street-journal/att-makes-progress-in-bid-for-time-warner/news-story/f7a2aa2b46515911620f31d89b97fdab
Didn't follow this question that closely.  Thank you @Anneinak for the comments.

http://marketrealist.com/2017/08/why-atts-new-structure-suggests-confidence-in-twx-deal-approval/ Why AT&T Still Believes It Can Close TWX Deal by End of the Year
By Andrew Smith  | Aug 29, 2017	 " . . .During AT&T’s recent 2Q17 earnings conference call, AT&T’s management reiterated its confidence in closing the proposed acquisition of Time Warner before the end of the year. However, the timing continues to be up in the air given the current uncertainty surrounding the Trump administration, specifically with respect to the DOJ (Department of Justice). Further, the management highlighted that AT&T’s merger integration team was nearly complete and was already looking at opportunities to improve advertising, bundling, and customer choice.
. . . 
"Despite the AT&T-Time Warner merger review being wrapped in uncertainty, AT&T (T) is moving forward with the groundwork for a new corporate structure made up of Time Warner’s (TWX) assets. AT&T is planning to run a dual organization structure following the closure of the proposed acquisition of Time Warner. Randall Stephenson will remain as the overall head of the combined company, but media and telecom operations will be separated into two distinct divisions led by two chief executives. "John Stankey, formerly the CEO (chief executive officer) of the Entertainment Group, will become the CEO of AT&T Media, which will include Time Warner’s assets such as HBO, Warner Bros, and Turner Cable, which runs CNN. John Donovan, who was formerly the chief strategy officer, will head AT&T Communications after the merger. The segment consists of wireless operations as well as the Entertainment Group, which includes DIRECTV. "A corporate structure like this would imply that AT&T wants to provide its news media operations the freedom it may require to be independent. Also, as per a few critics, when CNN comes under AT&T’s control, AT&T may attempt to exert editorial influence on CNN. President Donald Trump and CNN have shared a rocky relationship, and the president has repeatedly referred to the long-established news channel and media source as “fake news.”
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  This makes it sound like even by the end of the year is questionable.
Timeframe seems too short, too much is still to be done, especially politically.
Continuing my slow downward march to 0. Time is running out for this deal to be approved before 1 October, although I continue to expect that DoJ eventually will sign off on the merger.

I do not have any specific facts to add, just my analysis of those already presented.  Warren I see holding up the DoJ nominee and is obviously against  him and the merger.  Maybe she gives way some time in September.  Without him it's probably not going to happen by 10/1.   But even in Sept it is going to be tight.  I am going out on a limb and taking the under.

Downgrading, but still think its very possible for approval to be given within the next month, even without Delrahim. The noises are that the talks between AT&T and the DoJ are at an "advanced stage". https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-threatened-to-kill-the-at-t-time-warner-deal-but-its-very-much-alive-1502998077

There is an old expression about "running around like a chicken with its head cut off."  That is not the current situation in DoJ or most other federal agencies, including those headed by fixed-term appointees.  More like chickens whose heads were cut off about a week ago.  Nothing will happen, just as it has been with dizzying regularity for some time in most of the federal bureaucracy, until some adult leadership appears.  This is not imminent.

The DOJ needs an official leader! Without one, I don't see the approval happening before October 2017-maybe not before the end of 2017.
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/09/technology/att-time-warner-merger.html

Except a few things, the might have prepared their legal stuff very seriously. This is a yes.
Trump will probably try to explain he doesn't want this, but will have to step back. As usual ....
The project is for Dec 2017 and will also probably be delated to February 2018.

The deal will probably go through by the end of the year, but seems rather stretched to be completed by the end of September.
It seems that Delrahim's confirmation will not happen before September at the earliest, not much time for the deal to be approved by the question's deadline.
http://www.foxbusiness.com/features/2017/08/18/trump-threatened-to-kill-at-t-time-warner-deal-but-its-very-much-alive.html

.....because president Trump, singled out he is agaist a such bid, but it could be possible that the head of the justice dept., Makan Delrahim,could have another oppinion, about the merged trusts. It could be allso possible that the campaign trail of Trump, that he do not agree the hypothesys that AT&T buys Time Warner, would not be fulfilled, by the administration of President Trump.

https://seekingalpha.com/article/4101256-t-time-warner-latest-merger-update As of 23. Aug 2017 "As far as Trump goes, some have argued that he might re-stick his nose into the merger to gain a political win. It is hard to put anything past Trump these days, but we think a good base case is that he has bigger fish to fry than a cable TV deal. With last week's resignation of Steve Bannon, Trump no longer has the most vocal populist sounding off in his ear. So, this makes it even less likely. Regarding the DOJ, it is still missing its yet-to-confirmed head of the antitrust division. But DOJ approval can move forward without the appointee, Makan Delrahim, being confirmed. That is obviously a good thing considering the snail's pace of this Senate." We have 27 days to the deadline - I'd say that too short a timeframe for this thing to come through and hence my 15%.

http://deadline.com/2017/08/brazilian-antitrust-officials-question-att-bid-time-warner-1202153653/ "Brazil’s antitrust authorities may present bigger challenges to AT&T’s $85 billion bid for Time Warner than U.S. ones might.  A staff report from the country’s Administrative Council for Economic Defense — known as Cade — says the corporate union might violate laws that bar pay TV distributors from also owning content, Bloomberg reports."
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  AT&T folks are still saying that the process is on track for completion "by the end of the year".

Continuing my downward clock toward 0 because time is running out. Elizabeth Warren continues to block the Delrahim confirmation, although an update indicates she is now willing to meet with the nominee for DoJ's antitrust head. (http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/elizabeth-warren-refuses-to-meet-trump-nominee-shes-blocking-for-justice-antitrust-division/article/2631317) Same article points to Trump's equivocation about the AT&T / TimeWarner deal. Hard to see this as an urgent priority, even though AT&T continues to state publicly that the entire deal will be "closed" by year-end, which would require DoJ approval before then. http://www.barrons.com/articles/at-t-still-sees-time-warner-buy-by-year-end-1503309193 As always, I agree that the deal is likely to be approved - eventually. Just not by 1 October 2017. My sense is that the consensus forecast here on GJ Open is not sufficiently accounting for the closing date of this forecasting question.

The lower echelons of DoJ have no clear guidance on anything except that the current administration wishes them to get to work prosecuting anti-Nazis and affirmative action programs, and putting away low-level drug users for life or longer.  The folks at those levels are none too enthusiastic about these priorities and, like skilled administrators everwhere, are adept at dragging their collective feet when they want to.  As a result, most of the department's processes could be outrun by a reasonably brisk glacier at the moment.  And that's before you get to Mr. Tangerine Man's spasmodic hostility to the players in this case, which also comes before any actual substantive concerns.  Putting the brakes on this one; probably come down some more fairly soon.

I think that the chaos of the Trump administration and the short timeframe go against the merger. Chances are high that it will actually happen, but not soon enough for this prediction. If the baseline is 70%, this is certainly over-optimistic. As each day goes by, the odds on the other side will continue to go up. It is difficult to go against the wisdom of the crowd, but I think we are much closer to 50%.

http://marketrealist.com/2017/08/whats-really-stalling-the-att-time-warner-merger/ What’s Really Stalling the AT&T-Time Warner Merger?
By Rachel Gunter  | Aug 16, 2017	 "The proposed merger between AT&T (T) with Time Warner (TWX) has been under regulatory review for about eight months.  . . .  AT&T hopes that Time Warner’s media assets can help it overcome wireless competition driven by Verizon Communications (VZ), T-Mobile (TMUS), and Sprint (S).
. . . 
"But the already prolonged review of the AT&T-Time Warner merger could take even more time to complete, given President Trump’s vocal opposition to the deal as well as divisive issues and the leadership vacuum in the US Department of Justice. The size of the deal  [$85.4b] is also a factor, as it usually takes longer to complete the review of mega deals.  "More specifically, the US Senate has yet to approve the nomination of a top DOJ official in charge of antitrust cases. This official has the last word as to whether a deal goes through or flops. . . .  delays in the approval of Delrahim’s nomination will mean a longer wait for AT&T and Time Warner to know the fate of their deal. "Media reports have recently emerged that the White House was trying to interfere with the merger of AT&T and Time Warner by using its influence to criticize and challenge CNN’s coverage of the Trump administration. (CNN is owned by Time Warner.) Trump has shown open disdain for CNN, often referring to the long-established news outlet and media mainstay as “fake news.”  Notably, some lawmakers in Washington are concerned about Trump using the merger review as a bargaining chip to blunt media criticism of his administration. Sprint Brings More Attention to the AT&T-Time Warner Deal
" . . . recent media reports about Sprint (S) aggressively seeking a deal with a fellow wireless provider like T-Mobile (TMUS) or a cable company like Comcast (CMCSA) or Charter Communications (CHTR) have brought more attention to the potential implications of the AT&T-Time Warner deal. "There are, of course, fears that AT&T could raise content costs for other media companies after its swallows Time Warner. Dish Network (DISH) acquires content from Time Warner, and AT&T’s recent acquisition of DIRECTV and its subsequent launch of DIRECTV Now has brought it into more direct competition with Dish. In addition to offering satellite pay-TV, Dish runs a DIRECTV Now competitor, Sling TV. "There are also concerns that AT&T could make life harder for its smaller competitors by only promoting its own products, which would make it difficult for its rivals to pitch to its phone subscribers. "In what appears to complicate matters, AT&T has zero-rated DIRECTV Now so that it doesn’t account against the data plans of its phone customers. The company also offers free access to HBO to subscribers of its unlimited data plans. HBO, a product of Time Warner, normally costs $15 a month. "Now that Sprint is also on an expedition that could result in further wireless consolidation, there’s been renewed attention on how the AT&T-Time Warner merger could impact consumer choices and prices. The Truth about AT&T-Time Warner: Limited Room for the DOJ to Say No
". . .  A section of lawmakers in Washington and some industry players have expressed reservations about merging AT&T, a wireless giant, and Time Warner, a media and entertainment behemoth. Calls to deny the merger have largely centered on worries that it could reduce competition and harm consumers. Others have cited reduced choices for consumers and higher service prices as possible results if AT&T is allowed to swallow Time Warner after taking over DIRECTV. "Democratic and Republican lawmakers alike have either called for the denial of the AT&T-Time Warner deal or for stronger scrutiny of the deal. As a presidential candidate, Donald Trump spoke against the idea of combining the two companies, suggesting it would result in an extremely powerful entity. "Despite the opposition, the Department of Justice, which is reviewing the deal, seems to have limited room to deny AT&T-Time Warner merger outright. For example, the operations of AT&T and Time Warner have little overlap, if any. As such, the argument that combining them would harm the competition looks feeble. At the same time, Comcast’s acquisition of NBCUniversal in 2013 set a precedent that supports the course for combining AT&T and Time Warner. ". . .  AT&T wants to acquire Time Warner (TWX) as it believes buying this asset will dramatically transform its fortunes in a favorable way. Without a doubt, for rivals Verizon Communications (VZ), T-Mobile (TMUS), and Comcast (CMCSA), a merger of AT&T and Time Warner has all the trappings of a nightmare. "Despite what critics have been saying about AT&T-Time Warner merger, AT&T believes that it’s only a matter of time before it gets what it wants. The company expects regulators to have completed the review of the merger proposal by the end of the year. "Still, it’s been about eight months since regulators started looking into the deal. AT&T has reportedly spent millions of dollars in Washington lobbying for the merger. "Meanwhile, AT&T says that it doesn’t intend to bully competitors by restricting their access to Time Warner content. Several television networks rely on Time Warner for shows, and AT&T has its own pay-TV service that would put it in competition with some of Time Warner’s corporate customers. . . . AT&T chief Randall Stephenson stated the following in May: “You can’t think about taking ‘Game of Thrones,’ and you’re only going to make it available to AT&T customers. That’s crazy.” "As much as the AT&T-Time Warner merger review is still shrouded in uncertainties, AT&T (T) is going ahead with preparations for a new corporate structure made up of Time Warner’s (TWX) assets. " . . . Such a corporate structure would suggest that AT&T wants to give its news media operations the autonomy it would need to stay independent. But some critics have expressed fears that AT&T could try to exert editorial influence on CNN once it comes under its control. Notably, CNN has a rocky relationship with President Donald Trump, who has repeatedly referred to the long-established news outlet and media source as “fake news.”
. . . 	
"Although some media and telecom companies have voiced their opposition to AT&T (T) merging with Time Warner (TWX), they might do best to be careful with what they say to regulators to back their claims—it could make things difficult in the future. . . . If AT&T peers are contemplating mergers of their own, they’ll likely careful what they say, lest they endanger their own future consolidation deals.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I don't know what to think.  Are M&A proposals adjudicated on their merits?  or is it all just political?  I suspect it is a bit of both.  It sounds like it should be ok on the merits because there's little business overlap, but the politics aren't clear:  will DRT want to nix this because of his antipathy towards CNN or the size of the deal, or will he want to speed it up to show he's pro-business?  Will it be held up for confirmation of Delrahim, and how long will it take Delrahim to make up his mind on it, after confirmation?   The closing date of this question appears to also be an issue.

http://on.wsj.com/2wgazYa “The government review of AT&T Inc.’s $85 billion takeover of Time Warner Inc. has reached an advanced stage, people close to the situation said, a significant milestone in a deal that was closely watched for signs of how the Trump administration would view large mergers. The deal’s regulatory review has hit a late-stage point where AT&T lawyers are discussing merger conditions with the Justice Department, the people said. The review process has reached that point despite a vacant seat atop the department’s antitrust division. An approval could underscore the administration’s pro-business credentials at a time when President Donald Trump’s ties with America’s CEOs are under severe stress.” 
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Fellow forecasters, do any of you have any idea how long it might take AT&T lawyers & DoJ to agree on merger conditions?
I'm wondering if there might be a push from DRT to speed approval up to counter the negative news of the disbandment of two business advisory groups.

http://ew.com/tv/2017/08/15/cnn-trump-ad-criticizing-journalists/ In July, White House officials hinted to the New York Times that President Trump’s Justice Department might try to use the pending merger between Time Warner (CNN’s parent company) and AT&T as leverage over the network.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  This is the 2nd time I've read this in the last 2 days.  Is it a hint?
These things usually take longer than expected and this seems to have become a political football.

I divided this question into will they approve and if so, when.
Wisdom of the crowd was 70% so I used that as the baseline.
This in addition to the fact that the repuplicans is in power (which is more favorable to mergers) raises it by 10%. Donald trump lowers the odds by 5% however so it comes out at 75%
75% • the 95% of it being approved = 71.25%
taking into account the general trend so far and insecurity I will round it downward from 71.25 to 71

https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/05/business/media/jeffrey-zucker-cnn-trump.html?emc=edit_mbe_20170706&nl=morning-briefing-europe&nlid=77825025&te=1&_r=0 July 5, 2017,  " Mr. Trump’s Justice Department will decide whether to approve the [pending merger between CNN’s parent company, Time Warner, and AT&T], and while analysts say there is little to stop the deal from moving forward, the president’s animus toward CNN remains a wild card."
Nothing is getting done in TrumpLand
I think that this merger will go through, but I'm not convinced it'll be before Oct 1st.  I'll be watching this closely.
I hadn't heard about Warren delaying the antitrust nominee so I am dropping 30 points off my prediction and will probably keep going given how hard it is to get around a senate hold.

see @Reynard http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/550791 M&A is not an area that I know anything about, so I've been trying to figure out how long DOJ normally takes to review & approve a proposal. When Comcast was looking to take over Time-Warner, the DOJ had just begun--it seems--to review the proposal after 14 months. I note that the only thing I've found that mentions timing says simply, "by the end of the year". @shsmith330, @ErikFritzsche, @Rene, @acohen and others may know M&A, but I don't, so I'm lowering my forecast.

On a countdown to 0, due to timing. DoJ has recently begun talking with AT&T about merger conditions, but Bloomberg reports that the discussions are in early stages (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-24/at-t-said-to-be-in-early-u-s-talks-for-time-warner-approval). Meanwhile, Makan Delrahim, Trump's nominee to head DoJ's antitrust division has yet to be confirmed. His nomination was approved 19-1 by the Senate Judiciary Committee back in June, but Congress is on recess until September 5th, leaving less than one month for a confirmation vote before the expiration date of this forecasting question. With the debt ceiling and other pressing issues to be addressed in September, I don't expect this confirmation to be on the September calendar. And, I doubt that DoJ will act on such a major merger application until Delrahim is in place. Overall, I expect DoJ to approve the merger, but not until after 1 October 2017.
will happen but not likely before October 1st

AT&T’s proposed $109bn bid for Time Warner will be a test of Trump's attitudes about anti-trust regulations. When Comcast tried to take over Time-Warner, after more than 14 months it withdrew its offer because the DOJ was signaling it was going to block it.

Headlines today:	
AT&T's Time Warner Deal Looking Likely, Will It Be A Catalyst For The Stock?
Forbes
AT&T's proposed $85 billion acquisition of Time Warner is increasingly looking like a done deal. The acquisition is likely in the final stages of the

What I did you at this answer is I found the average of the two component probabilities of this question. Firstly, the probability of it being passed in general (regardless of timeframe), which I found to be .8. I think this because most evidence I found says that it has a strong chance, of approval, with few reasons it will not be. Next, the probability that it will be finalized by 1 Oct, 2017. I found this to be .4. I think this because most evidence suggests that there is a chance that it could be delayed, and is not in a rush. So, the average of .4 and .8 is .6.

#2. Optics of the situation. US regulatory setbacks dished out within a few month period in the communication industry left a bitter taste in many members of the populace.  So for all campaigns aiming to stop the deregulation were unsuccessful. Public pressure against the merger might intensify seeing Time Warner and AT&T as the last stand against media giants. (-40%)
#3. Presidential self-proclaimed stance against Time Warner merger, but the effect of President Trumps dissent is hard to estimate, as is his actual position (-5%).
#4. It comes down to timing. Is the DOJ willing to review before October 1? I think not.  Not when there are national intelligence whistleblowers and Russian collaborators running amok.  (-5%)

I see it as likely, but there are significant hurdles that have not been considered by many. First, the DOJ still must finish the review process. Second, according to a Reuters article, a decision concerning the merger will not be considered until an Assistant Attorney General has been appointed to oversee the anti-trust division. Lastly, although Trump is pro-big-business, something has to be said about the campaign promise to block this acquisition in particular. Yes, I know that he has limited reach, but I would not put it past him to make deals, before appointing anyone, to at least postpone this merger.  All in all, while everyone else is postive about this happening, I'll be the nay-sayer.

Makan Delrahim, a former Justice Department antitrust lawyer now working at the White House, told Canadian business news channel BNN last year that the Time Warner deal doesn’t raise the same hurdles as a merger of two direct competitors, because it would unite a distributor and a content provider. "Just the sheer size of it and the fact that it’s media, I think will get a lot of attention," he said in the October 24 interview . "However, I don’t see this as a major antitrust problem." Those remarks set up a potential clash with an administration that has prized loyalty to its agenda. Delrahim is Trump’s pick to lead the antitrust division, people familiar with the matter have said, which would put him in charge of some of the government’s biggest merger reviews -- the $85 billion Time Warner takeover, as well as pending tie-ups between Bayer AG and Monsanto Co. and Dow Chemical Co. and DuPont Co.
https://finance.yahoo.com/news/trump-antitrust-pick-saw-few-155319597.html most analysts expect AT&T to successfully consummate its merger with media giant Time Warner. Already The European Commission has signed off on AT&T’s bid to acquire Time Warner. But while the proposed $85 billion merger is likely to face an antitrust review by the Justice Department, there is still some question of whether AT&T and Time Warner will have to contend with the FCC’s public-interest review. The FCC’s new chairman, Ajit Pai, has told The Wall Street Journal that, since the companies put together the deal so that no FCC licenses need to be transferred, the FCC won’t be involved. As for AT&T top management, they have continued to believe that the deal will ultimately close by the end of this year. “We remain confident that the deal will be approved later this year,” AT&T CFO John Stephens told investors last month.

I am moving this up as the FCC says it will not be involved.

The head of the U.S. Federal Communications Commission does not expect to review AT&T Inc's (T.N) planned $85.4 billion acquisition of Time Warner Inc (TWX.N), a spokesman for the agency said on Monday. FCC Chairman Ajit Pai had told the Wall Street Journal in an interview on Monday at the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona that he did not foresee a role for the FCC on the takeover and his comments were confirmed to Reuters by FCC spokesman Neil Grace. Last Thursday, Time Warner said it plans to sell a broadcast station in Atlanta to Meredith Corp for $70 million, which could help speed the company's planned merger with AT&T. Pai declined to say on Thursday if he would use that transfer to try to review the broader merger. In January, AT&T said it expected to be able to bypass the FCC because it would not seek to transfer any Time Warner licenses. About a dozen U.S. senators have urged him to review the deal. The station that Time Warner is selling, WPCH-TV in Atlanta, is its only FCC-regulated broadcast station. It has other, more minor FCC licenses. Meredith has operated WPCH-TV for Time Warner since 2011. It was previously know as WTBS. Time Warner said last month it expected it would only need the consent of the U.S. Department of Justice. The Justice Department, which is reviewing documents submitted on the proposed merger, has to prove a proposed deal harms competition in order to block it. The FCC has broad leeway to block a merger it deems is not in the "public interest" and can impose additional conditions. AT&T Chief Executive Randall Stephenson told CNBC earlier this month the Justice Department review was ongoing and he thought the deal would close by the end of the year. "It's a clean transaction," he said.

Sessions will probably be confirmed as Attorney General despite the negative attention brought to his character by the Republican Senate's formal silencing of Sen. Warren. If DeVos could be confirmed, there's almost no way Sessions won't, as a more senior member of the Senate. Looking at precedent, Sessions will have to follow orders from Trump, or risk being fired as Sally Yates did, so if he's ordered to interfere with the merger, the Department Of Justice will likely attempt to block the merger. The chaos and confusion that resulted from some of Trump's executive orders has partially been due to lack of experience, judgement, and a strange retributive desire to shock and awe; But when Secretary of State Tillerson was confirmed, some order and clarity was restored, indicating that another factor has been a lack of direction, leadership and expertise. Just as Tillerson appears to have salvaged the Department of State, it's possible that Sessions' influence could moderate Trump's unchecked desire to ruin CNN (subsidiary of Time Warner), especially if someone sweetens the deal for the administration or member thereof. But it gets slightly more complicated because Republicans tend to be more relaxed with mergers than Democrats, so the only opposition would be by Republicans, and we haven't seen anyone but McCain and Rand Paul oppose Trump's policies, and only in certain instances.
